001package squidpony.squidgrid.mapping;
002
003import squidpony.squidgrid.Direction;
004import squidpony.squidmath.*;
005
006import java.util.ArrayList;
007import java.util.Arrays;
008import java.util.List;
009import java.util.Map;
010
011/**
012 * A dungeon generator that can use a mix of techniques to have part-cave, part-room dungeons. Not entirely intended for
013 * normal use outside of this library, though it can be very useful when you want to make a dungeon match a specific
014 * path and existing generators that use MixedGenerator aren't sufficient. You may want to use a simpler generator based
015 * on this, like SerpentMapGenerator, which generates a long, winding path that loops around on itself. This supports
016 * the getEnvironment() method, which can be used in conjunction with RoomFinder to find where separate room, corridor,
017 * and cave areas have been placed.
018 * <br>
019 * Based on Michael Patraw's excellent Drunkard's Walk dungeon generator.
020 * http://mpatraw.github.io/libdrunkard/
021 * @see squidpony.squidgrid.mapping.SerpentMapGenerator a normal use for MixedGenerator that makes winding dungeons
022 * @see squidpony.squidgrid.mapping.SerpentDeepMapGenerator uses MixedGenerator as it makes a multi-level dungeon
023 * Created by Tommy Ettinger on 10/22/2015.
024 */
025public class MixedGenerator implements IDungeonGenerator {     
026    public static final int CAVE = 0,
027        BOX = 1,
028        ROUND = 2,
029        BOX_WALLED = 3,
030        ROUND_WALLED = 4;
031
032    /**
033     * Constant for environment tiles that are not near a cave, room, or corridor. Value is 0.
034     * Used by several classes that distinguish types of dungeon environment, like {@link SectionDungeonGenerator}.
035     * Present here for compatibility; you should prefer {@link DungeonUtility#UNTOUCHED}.
036     */
037    public static final int UNTOUCHED = 0;
038    /**
039     * Constant for environment tiles that are floors for a room. Value is 1.
040     * Used by several classes that distinguish types of dungeon environment, like {@link SectionDungeonGenerator}.
041     * Present here for compatibility; you should prefer {@link DungeonUtility#ROOM_FLOOR}.
042     */
043    public static final int ROOM_FLOOR = 1;
044    /**
045     * Constant for environment tiles that are walls near a room. Value is 2.
046     * Used by several classes that distinguish types of dungeon environment, like {@link SectionDungeonGenerator}.
047     * Present here for compatibility; you should prefer {@link DungeonUtility#ROOM_WALL}.
048     */
049    public static final int ROOM_WALL = 2;
050    /**
051     * Constant for environment tiles that are floors for a cave. Value is 3.
052     * Used by several classes that distinguish types of dungeon environment, like {@link SectionDungeonGenerator}.
053     * Present here for compatibility; you should prefer {@link DungeonUtility#CAVE_FLOOR}.
054     */
055    public static final int CAVE_FLOOR = 3;
056    /**
057     * Constant for environment tiles that are walls near a cave. Value is 4.
058     * Used by several classes that distinguish types of dungeon environment, like {@link SectionDungeonGenerator}.
059     * Present here for compatibility; you should prefer {@link DungeonUtility#CAVE_WALL}.
060     */
061    public static final int CAVE_WALL = 4;
062    /**
063     * Constant for environment tiles that are floors for a corridor. Value is 5.
064     * Used by several classes that distinguish types of dungeon environment, like {@link SectionDungeonGenerator}.
065     * Present here for compatibility; you should prefer {@link DungeonUtility#CORRIDOR_FLOOR}.
066     */
067    public static final int CORRIDOR_FLOOR = 5;
068    /**
069     * Constant for environment tiles that are walls near a corridor. Value is 6.
070     * Used by several classes that distinguish types of dungeon environment, like {@link SectionDungeonGenerator}.
071     * Present here for compatibility; you should prefer {@link DungeonUtility#CORRIDOR_WALL}.
072     */
073    public static final int CORRIDOR_WALL = 6;
074
075    //protected EnumMap<CarverType, Integer> carvers;
076    protected double[] carvers;
077    protected WeightedTable carverTable;
078    protected int width, height;
079    protected float roomWidth, roomHeight;
080    public IRNG rng;
081    protected char[][] dungeon;
082    protected boolean generated = false;
083    protected int[][] environment;
084    protected boolean[][] marked, walled, fixedRooms;
085    protected IntVLA points;
086    protected int totalPoints;
087
088    /**
089     * Mainly for internal use; this is used by {@link #MixedGenerator(int, int, IRNG)} to get its room positions.
090     * This is (and was) the default for generating a List of Coord if no other collection of Coord was supplied to the
091     * constructor. For some time this was not the default, and {@link #cleanPoints(int, int, IRNG)} was used instead.
092     * Both are still options, but this technique seems to keep corridors shorter and makes connections between rooms
093     * more relevant to the current area.
094     * <br>
095     * <a href="https://gist.githubusercontent.com/tommyettinger/be0ed51858cb492bc7e8cda43a04def1/raw/dae9d8e4f45dd3a3577bdd5f58b419ea5f9ed570/PoissonDungeon.txt">Preview map.</a>
096     * @param width dungeon width in cells
097     * @param height dungeon height in cells
098     * @param rng rng to use
099     * @return evenly spaced Coord points in a list made by PoissonDisk, trimmed down so they aren't all used
100     * @see PoissonDisk used to make the list
101     */
102    public static OrderedSet<Coord> basicPoints(int width, int height, IRNG rng)
103    {
104        return PoissonDisk.sampleRectangle(Coord.get(2, 2), Coord.get(width - 3, height - 3),
105                8.5f * (width + height) / 120f, width, height, 35, rng);
106    }
107    /**
108     * Mainly for internal use; this was used by {@link #MixedGenerator(int, int, IRNG)} to get its room positions, and
109     * you can choose to use it with {@code new MixedGenerator(width, height, rng, cleanPoints(width, height, rng))}.
110     * It produces a fairly rigid layout of rooms that should have less overlap between rooms and corridors; the
111     * downside to this is that corridors can become extremely long. The exact technique used here is to get points from
112     * a Halton-like sequence, formed using {@link VanDerCorputQRNG} to get a van der Corput sequence, for the x axis
113     * and a scrambled van der Corput sequence for the y axis. MixedGenerator will connect these points in pairs. The
114     * current method is much better at avoiding "clumps" of closely-positioned rooms in the center of the map.
115     * <br>
116     * <a href="https://gist.githubusercontent.com/tommyettinger/2745e6fc16fc2acebe2fc959fb4e4c2e/raw/77e1f4dbc844d8892c1a686754535c02cadaa270/TenDungeons.txt">Preview maps, with and without box drawing characters.</a>
117     * Note that one of the dungeons in that gist was produced as a fallback by {@link DungeonGenerator} with no
118     * arguments (using DEFAULT_DUNGEON as the dungeon style), because the map this method produced in one case had too
119     * few floor cells to be used.
120     * @param width dungeon width in cells
121     * @param height dungeon height in cells
122     * @param rng rng to use
123     * @return erratically-positioned but generally separated Coord points to pass to a MixedGenerator constructor
124     * @see VanDerCorputQRNG used to get separated positions
125     */
126    public static List<Coord> cleanPoints(int width, int height, IRNG rng)
127    {
128        width -= 2;
129        height -= 2;
130        //float mx = rng.nextFloat() * 0.2f, my = rng.nextFloat() * 0.2f;
131        int blocks = width * height / 640, sz = blocks * 5, index = 0,
132                seed = rng.nextInt()|1, seed2 = rng.nextInt()|1;
133        //System.out.println("mx: " + mx + ", my: " + my + ", index: " + index);
134        List<Coord> list = new ArrayList<>(sz);
135        for (int i = 0; i < blocks; i++) {
136            Coord area = VanDerCorputQRNG.haltoid(seed, width * 3 >> 2, height * 3 >> 2, 1, 1, i);
137            for (int j = 0; j < 5; j++) {
138                list.add(VanDerCorputQRNG.haltoid(seed2, width >> 2, height >> 2, area.x, area.y, index++));
139            }
140        }
141        return list;
142    }
143
144    /**
145     * This prepares a map generator that will generate a map with the given width and height, using the given RNG.
146     * This version of the constructor uses a sub-random point sequence to generate the points it will draw caves and
147     * corridors between, helping to ensure a minimum distance between points, but it does not ensure that paths between
148     * points  will avoid overlapping with rooms or other paths. You call the different carver-adding methods to affect
149     * what the dungeon will look like, putCaveCarvers(), putBoxRoomCarvers(), and putRoundRoomCarvers(), defaulting to
150     * only caves if none are called. You call generate() after adding carvers, which returns a char[][] for a map.
151     * @param width the width of the final map in cells
152     * @param height the height of the final map in cells
153     * @param rng an RNG object to use for random choices; this make a lot of random choices.
154     * @see PoissonDisk used to ensure spacing for the points.
155     */
156    public MixedGenerator(int width, int height, IRNG rng) {
157        this(width, height, rng, cleanPoints(width, height, rng));
158    }
159
160    /**
161     * This prepares a map generator that will generate a map with the given width and height, using the given RNG.
162     * This version of the constructor uses a List of Coord points from some other source to determine the path to add
163     * rooms or caves to and then connect. You call the different carver-adding methods to affect what the
164     * dungeon will look like, putCaveCarvers(), putBoxRoomCarvers(), and putRoundRoomCarvers(), defaulting to only
165     * caves if none are called. You call generate() after adding carvers, which returns a char[][] for a map.
166     * @param width the width of the final map in cells
167     * @param height the height of the final map in cells
168     * @param rng an RNG object to use for random choices; this make a lot of random choices.
169     * @param sequence a List of Coord to connect in order; index 0 is the start, index size() - 1 is the end.
170     * @see SerpentMapGenerator a class that uses this technique
171     */
172    public MixedGenerator(int width, int height, IRNG rng, List<Coord> sequence) {
173        this.width = width;
174        this.height = height;
175        this.roomWidth = width / 64.0f;
176        this.roomHeight = height / 64.0f;
177        if(width <= 2 || height <= 2)
178            throw new IllegalStateException("width and height must be greater than 2");
179        this.rng = rng;
180        dungeon = new char[width][height];
181        environment = new int[width][height];
182        marked = new boolean[width][height];
183        walled = new boolean[width][height];
184        fixedRooms = new boolean[width][height];
185        Arrays.fill(dungeon[0], '#');
186        Arrays.fill(environment[0], DungeonUtility.UNTOUCHED);
187        for (int i = 1; i < width; i++) {
188            System.arraycopy(dungeon[0], 0, dungeon[i], 0, height);
189            System.arraycopy(environment[0], 0, environment[i], 0, height);
190        }
191        totalPoints = sequence.size() - 1;
192        points = new IntVLA(totalPoints);
193        for (int i = 0; i < totalPoints; i++) {
194            Coord c1 = sequence.get(i), c2 = sequence.get(i + 1);
195            points.add(((c1.x & 0xff) << 24) | ((c1.y & 0xff) << 16) | ((c2.x & 0xff) << 8) | (c2.y & 0xff));
196        }
197        carvers = new double[5];
198    }
199    /**
200     * This prepares a map generator that will generate a map with the given width and height, using the given IRNG.
201     * This version of the constructor uses a Map with Coord keys and Coord array values to determine a
202     * branching path for the dungeon to take; each key will connect once to each of the Coords in its value, and you
203     * usually don't want to connect in both directions. You call the different carver-adding methods to affect what the
204     * dungeon will look like, putCaveCarvers(), putBoxRoomCarvers(), and putRoundRoomCarvers(), defaulting to only
205     * caves if none are called. You call generate() after adding carvers, which returns a char[][] for a map.
206     * @param width the width of the final map in cells
207     * @param height the height of the final map in cells
208     * @param rng an IRNG object to use for random choices; this make a lot of random choices.
209     * @param connections a Map of Coord keys to arrays of Coord to connect to next; shouldn't connect both ways
210     * @see SerpentMapGenerator a class that uses this technique
211     */
212    public MixedGenerator(int width, int height, IRNG rng, Map<Coord, List<Coord>> connections)
213    {
214        this(width, height, rng, connections, 0.8f);
215    }
216    /**
217     * This prepares a map generator that will generate a map with the given width and height, using the given IRNG.
218     * This version of the constructor uses a Map with Coord keys and Coord array values to determine a
219     * branching path for the dungeon to take; each key will connect once to each of the Coords in its value, and you
220     * usually don't want to connect in both directions. You call the different carver-adding methods to affect what the
221     * dungeon will look like, putCaveCarvers(), putBoxRoomCarvers(), and putRoundRoomCarvers(), defaulting to only
222     * caves if none are called. You call generate() after adding carvers, which returns a char[][] for a map.
223     * @param width the width of the final map in cells
224     * @param height the height of the final map in cells
225     * @param rng an IRNG object to use for random choices; this make a lot of random choices.
226     * @param connections a Map of Coord keys to arrays of Coord to connect to next; shouldn't connect both ways
227     * @param roomSizeMultiplier a float multiplier that will be applied to each room's width and height
228     * @see SerpentMapGenerator a class that uses this technique
229     */
230    public MixedGenerator(int width, int height, IRNG rng, Map<Coord, List<Coord>> connections,
231                          float roomSizeMultiplier) {
232        this.width = width;
233        this.height = height;
234        roomWidth = (width / 64.0f) * roomSizeMultiplier;
235        roomHeight = (height / 64.0f) * roomSizeMultiplier;
236        if(width <= 2 || height <= 2)
237            throw new IllegalStateException("width and height must be greater than 2");
238        this.rng = rng;
239        dungeon = new char[width][height];
240        environment = new int[width][height];
241        marked = new boolean[width][height];
242        walled = new boolean[width][height];
243        fixedRooms = new boolean[width][height];
244        Arrays.fill(dungeon[0], '#');
245        Arrays.fill(environment[0], DungeonUtility.UNTOUCHED);
246        for (int i = 1; i < width; i++) {
247            System.arraycopy(dungeon[0], 0, dungeon[i], 0, height);
248            System.arraycopy(environment[0], 0, environment[i], 0, height);
249        }
250        totalPoints = 0;
251        for(List<Coord> vals : connections.values())
252        {
253            totalPoints += vals.size();
254        }
255        points = new IntVLA(totalPoints);
256        for (Map.Entry<Coord, List<Coord>> kv : connections.entrySet()) {
257            Coord c1 = kv.getKey();
258            for (Coord c2 : kv.getValue()) {
259                points.add(((c1.x & 0xff) << 24) | ((c1.y & 0xff) << 16) | ((c2.x & 0xff) << 8) | (c2.y & 0xff));
260            }
261        }
262        carvers = new double[5];
263    }
264    
265    /**
266     * Changes the number of "carvers" that will create caves from one room to the next. If count is 0 or less, no caves
267     * will be made. If count is at least 1, caves are possible, and higher numbers relative to the other carvers make
268     * caves more likely. Carvers are shuffled when used, then repeat if exhausted during generation. Since typically
269     * about 30-40 rooms are carved, large totals for carver count aren't really needed; aiming for a total of 10
270     * between the count of putCaveCarvers(), putBoxRoomCarvers(), putRoundRoomCarvers(), putWalledBoxRoomCarvers(), and
271     * putWalledRoundRoomCarvers() is reasonable.
272     * @param count the number of carvers making caves between rooms; only matters in relation to other carvers
273     */
274    public void putCaveCarvers(int count)
275    {
276        carvers[CAVE] = count;
277    }
278    /**
279     * Changes the number of "carvers" that will create right-angle corridors from one room to the next, create rooms
280     * with a random size in a box shape at the start and end, and a small room at the corner if there is one. If count
281     * is 0 or less, no box-shaped rooms will be made. If count is at least 1, box-shaped rooms are possible, and higher
282     * numbers relative to the other carvers make box-shaped rooms more likely. Carvers are shuffled when used, then
283     * repeat if exhausted during generation. Since typically about 30-40 rooms are carved, large totals for carver
284     * count aren't really needed; aiming for a total of 10 between the count of putCaveCarvers(), putBoxRoomCarvers(),
285     * putRoundRoomCarvers(), putWalledBoxRoomCarvers(), and putWalledRoundRoomCarvers() is reasonable.
286     * @param count the number of carvers making box-shaped rooms and corridors between them; only matters in relation
287     *              to other carvers
288     */
289    public void putBoxRoomCarvers(int count)
290    {
291        carvers[BOX] = count;
292    }
293
294    /**
295     * Changes the number of "carvers" that will create right-angle corridors from one room to the next, create rooms
296     * with a random size in a circle shape at the start and end, and a small circular room at the corner if there is
297     * one. If count is 0 or less, no circular rooms will be made. If count is at least 1, circular rooms are possible,
298     * and higher numbers relative to the other carvers make circular rooms more likely. Carvers are shuffled when used,
299     * then repeat if exhausted during generation. Since typically about 30-40 rooms are carved, large totals for carver
300     * count aren't really needed; aiming for a total of 10 between the count of putCaveCarvers(), putBoxRoomCarvers(),
301     * putRoundRoomCarvers(), putWalledBoxRoomCarvers(), and putWalledRoundRoomCarvers() is reasonable.
302     * @param count the number of carvers making circular rooms and corridors between them; only matters in relation
303     *              to other carvers
304     */
305    public void putRoundRoomCarvers(int count)
306    {
307        carvers[ROUND] = count;
308    }
309    /**
310     * Changes the number of "carvers" that will create right-angle corridors from one room to the next, create rooms
311     * with a random size in a box shape at the start and end, and a small room at the corner if there is one, enforcing
312     * the presence of walls around the rooms even if another room is already there or would be placed there. Corridors
313     * can always pass through enforced walls, but caves will open at most one cell in the wall. If count
314     * is 0 or less, no box-shaped rooms will be made. If count is at least 1, box-shaped rooms are possible, and higher
315     * numbers relative to the other carvers make box-shaped rooms more likely. Carvers are shuffled when used, then
316     * repeat if exhausted during generation. Since typically about 30-40 rooms are carved, large totals for carver
317     * count aren't really needed; aiming for a total of 10 between the count of putCaveCarvers(), putBoxRoomCarvers(),
318     * putRoundRoomCarvers(), putWalledBoxRoomCarvers(), and putWalledRoundRoomCarvers() is reasonable.
319     * @param count the number of carvers making box-shaped rooms and corridors between them; only matters in relation
320     *              to other carvers
321     */
322    public void putWalledBoxRoomCarvers(int count)
323    {
324        carvers[BOX_WALLED] = count;
325    }
326
327    /**
328     * Changes the number of "carvers" that will create right-angle corridors from one room to the next, create rooms
329     * with a random size in a circle shape at the start and end, and a small circular room at the corner if there is
330     * one, enforcing the presence of walls around the rooms even if another room is already there or would be placed
331     * there. Corridors can always pass through enforced walls, but caves will open at most one cell in the wall. If
332     * count is 0 or less, no circular rooms will be made. If count is at least 1, circular rooms are possible,
333     * and higher numbers relative to the other carvers make circular rooms more likely. Carvers are shuffled when used,
334     * then repeat if exhausted during generation. Since typically about 30-40 rooms are carved, large totals for carver
335     * count aren't really needed; aiming for a total of 10 between the count of putCaveCarvers(), putBoxRoomCarvers(),
336     * putRoundRoomCarvers(), putWalledBoxRoomCarvers(), and putWalledRoundRoomCarvers() is reasonable.
337     * @param count the number of carvers making circular rooms and corridors between them; only matters in relation
338     *              to other carvers
339     */
340    public void putWalledRoundRoomCarvers(int count)
341    {
342        carvers[ROUND_WALLED] = count;
343    }
344
345    /**
346     * Uses the added carvers (or just makes caves if none were added) to carve from point to point in sequence, if it
347     * was provided by the constructor, or evenly-spaced randomized points if it was not. This will never carve out
348     * cells on the very edge of the map. Uses the numbers of the various kinds of carver that were added relative to
349     * each other to determine how frequently to use a given carver type.
350     * @return a char[][] where '#' is a wall and '.' is a floor or corridor; x first y second
351     */
352    public char[][] generate()
353    {
354        if(carvers[0] <= 0 && carvers[1] <= 0 && carvers[2] <= 0 && carvers[3] <= 0 && carvers[4] <= 0)
355            carvers[0] = 1;
356        carverTable = new WeightedTable(carvers);
357//        CarverType[] carvings = carvers.keySet().toArray(new CarverType[carvers.size()]);
358//        int[] carvingsCounters = new int[carvings.length];
359//        int totalLength = 0;
360//        for (int i = 0; i < carvings.length; i++) {
361//            carvingsCounters[i] = carvers.get(carvings[i]);
362//            totalLength += carvingsCounters[i];
363//        }
364//        CarverType[] allCarvings = new CarverType[totalLength];
365//
366//        for (int i = 0, c = 0; i < carvings.length; i++) {
367//            for (int j = 0; j < carvingsCounters[i]; j++) {
368//                allCarvings[c++] = carvings[i];
369//            }
370//        }
371//        if(allCarvings.length == 0)
372//        {
373//            allCarvings = new CarverType[]{CarverType.CAVE};
374//            totalLength = 1;
375//        }
376//        else
377//            allCarvings = rng.shuffle(allCarvings, new CarverType[allCarvings.length]);
378
379        for (int p = 0; p < totalPoints; p++) {
380            int pair = points.get(p);
381            Coord start = Coord.get(pair >>> 24 & 0xff, pair >>> 16 & 0xff),
382                  end   = Coord.get(pair >>> 8 & 0xff, pair & 0xff);
383            int ct = carverTable.random(rng.nextLong());
384            Direction dir;
385            switch (ct)
386            {
387                case CAVE:
388                    markPiercing(end);
389                    markEnvironmentCave(end.x, end.y);
390                    store();
391                    double weight = 0.75;
392                    do {
393                        Coord cent = markPlusCave(start);
394                        if(cent != null)
395                        {
396                            markPiercingCave(cent);
397                            markPiercingCave(cent.translate(1, 0));
398                            markPiercingCave(cent.translate(-1, 0));
399                            markPiercingCave(cent.translate(0, 1));
400                            markPiercingCave(cent.translate(0, -1));
401                            weight = 0.95;
402                        }
403                        dir = stepWobbly(start, end, weight);
404                        start = start.translate(dir);
405                    }while (dir != Direction.NONE);
406                    break;
407                case BOX:
408                    markRectangle(end, rng.between(1, 5), rng.between(1, 5));
409                    markRectangle(start, rng.between(1, 4), rng.between(1, 4));
410                    store();
411                    dir = Direction.getDirection(end.x - start.x, end.y - start.y);
412                    if(dir.isDiagonal())
413                        dir = rng.nextBoolean() ? Direction.getCardinalDirection(dir.deltaX, 0)
414                                : Direction.getCardinalDirection(0, -dir.deltaY);
415                    while (start.x != end.x && start.y != end.y)
416                    {
417                        markPiercing(start);
418                        markEnvironmentCorridor(start.x, start.y);
419                        start = start.translate(dir);
420                    }
421                    markRectangle(start, 1, 1);
422                    dir = Direction.getCardinalDirection(end.x - start.x, -(end.y - start.y));
423                    while (!(start.x == end.x && start.y == end.y))
424                    {
425                        markPiercing(start);
426                        markEnvironmentCorridor(start.x, start.y);
427                        start = start.translate(dir);
428                    }
429                    break;
430                case BOX_WALLED:
431                    markRectangleWalled(end, rng.between(1, 5), rng.between(1, 5));
432                    markRectangleWalled(start, rng.between(1, 4), rng.between(1, 4));
433                    store();
434                    dir = Direction.getDirection(end.x - start.x, end.y - start.y);
435                    if(dir.isDiagonal())
436                        dir = rng.nextBoolean() ? Direction.getCardinalDirection(dir.deltaX, 0)
437                                : Direction.getCardinalDirection(0, -dir.deltaY);
438                    while (start.x != end.x && start.y != end.y)
439                    {
440                        markPiercing(start);
441                        markEnvironmentCorridor(start.x, start.y);
442                        start = start.translate(dir);
443                    }
444                    markRectangleWalled(start, 1, 1);
445                    dir = Direction.getCardinalDirection(end.x - start.x, -(end.y - start.y));
446                    while (!(start.x == end.x && start.y == end.y))
447                    {
448                        markPiercing(start);
449                        markEnvironmentCorridor(start.x, start.y);
450                        start = start.translate(dir);
451                    }
452                    break;
453                case ROUND:
454                    markCircle(end, rng.between(2, 6));
455                    markCircle(start, rng.between(2, 6));
456                    store();
457                    dir = Direction.getDirection(end.x - start.x, end.y - start.y);
458                    if(dir.isDiagonal())
459                        dir = rng.nextBoolean() ? Direction.getCardinalDirection(dir.deltaX, 0)
460                                : Direction.getCardinalDirection(0, -dir.deltaY);
461                    while (start.x != end.x && start.y != end.y)
462                    {
463                        markPiercing(start);
464                        markEnvironmentCorridor(start.x, start.y);
465                        start = start.translate(dir);
466                    }
467                    markCircle(start, 2);
468                    dir = Direction.getCardinalDirection(end.x - start.x, -(end.y - start.y));
469                    while (!(start.x == end.x && start.y == end.y))
470                    {
471                        markPiercing(start);
472                        markEnvironmentCorridor(start.x, start.y);
473                        start = start.translate(dir);
474                    }
475                    break;
476                case ROUND_WALLED:
477                    markCircleWalled(end, rng.between(2, 6));
478                    markCircleWalled(start, rng.between(2, 6));
479                    store();
480                    dir = Direction.getDirection(end.x - start.x, end.y - start.y);
481                    if(dir.isDiagonal())
482                        dir = rng.nextBoolean() ? Direction.getCardinalDirection(dir.deltaX, 0)
483                                : Direction.getCardinalDirection(0, -dir.deltaY);
484                    while (start.x != end.x && start.y != end.y)
485                    {
486                        markPiercing(start);
487                        markEnvironmentCorridor(start.x, start.y);
488                        start = start.translate(dir);
489                    }
490                    markCircleWalled(start, 2);
491                    dir = Direction.getCardinalDirection(end.x - start.x, -(end.y - start.y));
492                    while (!(start.x == end.x && start.y == end.y))
493                    {
494                        markPiercing(start);
495                        markEnvironmentCorridor(start.x, start.y);
496                        start = start.translate(dir);
497                    }
498                    break;
499            }
500            store();
501        }
502        for (int x = 0; x < width; x++) {
503            for (int y = 0; y < height; y++) {
504                if(fixedRooms[x][y])
505                    markPiercingRoom(x, y);
506            }
507        }
508        store();
509        markEnvironmentWalls();
510        generated = true;
511        return dungeon;
512    }
513
514    public char[][] getDungeon() {
515        return dungeon;
516    }
517
518    public int[][] getEnvironment()
519    {
520        return environment;
521    }
522
523    public boolean hasGenerated()
524    {
525        return generated;
526    }
527
528    public boolean[][] getFixedRooms() {
529        return fixedRooms;
530    }
531
532    public void setFixedRooms(boolean[][] fixedRooms) {
533        this.fixedRooms = fixedRooms;
534    }
535
536    /**
537     * Internal use. Takes cells that have been previously marked and permanently stores them as floors in the dungeon.
538     */
539    protected void store()
540    {
541        for (int i = 0; i < width; i++) {
542            for (int j = 0; j < height; j++) {
543                if(marked[i][j])
544                {
545                    dungeon[i][j] = '.';
546                    marked[i][j] = false;
547                }
548            }
549        }
550    }
551
552    /**
553     * Internal use. Finds all floor cells by environment and marks untouched adjacent (8-way) cells as walls, using the
554     * appropriate type for the nearby floor.
555     */
556    protected void markEnvironmentWalls()
557    {
558        for (int i = 0; i < width; i++) {
559            for (int j = 0; j < height; j++) {
560                if(environment[i][j] == DungeonUtility.UNTOUCHED)
561                {
562                    boolean allWalls = true;
563                    //lowest precedence, also checks for any floors
564                    for (int x = Math.max(0, i - 1); x <= Math.min(width - 1, i + 1); x++) {
565
566                        for (int y = Math.max(0, j - 1); y <= Math.min(height - 1, j + 1); y++) {
567                            if (environment[x][y] == DungeonUtility.CORRIDOR_FLOOR) {
568                                markEnvironment(i, j, DungeonUtility.CORRIDOR_WALL);
569                            }
570                            if(dungeon[x][y] == '.')
571                                allWalls = false;
572                        }
573                    }
574                    //if there are no floors we don't need to check twice again.
575                    if(allWalls)
576                        continue;
577                    //more precedence
578                    for (int x = Math.max(0, i - 1); x <= Math.min(width - 1, i + 1); x++) {
579
580                        for (int y = Math.max(0, j - 1); y <= Math.min(height - 1, j + 1); y++) {
581                            if (environment[x][y] == DungeonUtility.CAVE_FLOOR) {
582                                markEnvironment(i, j, DungeonUtility.CAVE_WALL);
583                            }
584                        }
585                    }
586                    //highest precedence
587                    for (int x = Math.max(0, i - 1); x <= Math.min(width - 1, i + 1); x++) {
588
589                        for (int y = Math.max(0, j - 1); y <= Math.min(height - 1, j + 1); y++) {
590                            if (environment[x][y] == DungeonUtility.ROOM_FLOOR) {
591                                markEnvironment(i, j, DungeonUtility.ROOM_WALL);
592                            }
593                        }
594                    }
595
596                }
597            }
598        }
599    }
600
601    /**
602     * Internal use. Marks a point to be made into floor.
603     * @param x x position to mark
604     * @param y y position to mark
605     * @return false if everything is normal, true if and only if this failed to mark because the position is walled
606     */
607    protected boolean mark(int x, int y) {
608        if (x > 0 && x < width - 1 && y > 0 && y < height - 1 && !walled[x][y]) {
609            marked[x][y] = true;
610            return false;
611        }
612        else return x > 0 && x < width - 1 && y > 0 && y < height - 1 && walled[x][y];
613    }
614
615    /**
616     * Internal use. Marks a point to be made into floor.
617     * @param x x position to mark
618     * @param y y position to mark
619     */
620    protected void markPiercing(int x, int y) {
621        if (x > 0 && x < width - 1 && y > 0 && y < height - 1) {
622            marked[x][y] = true;
623        }
624    }
625    /**
626     * Internal use. Marks a point's environment type as the appropriate kind of environment.
627     * @param x x position to mark
628     * @param y y position to mark
629     * @param kind an int that should be one of the constants in MixedGenerator for environment types.
630     */
631    protected void markEnvironment(int x, int y, int kind) {
632        environment[x][y] = kind;
633    }
634
635    /**
636     * Internal use. Marks a point's environment type as a corridor floor.
637     * @param x x position to mark
638     * @param y y position to mark
639     */
640    protected void markEnvironmentCorridor(int x, int y) {
641        if (x > 0 && x < width - 1 && y > 0 && y < height - 1 && environment[x][y] != DungeonUtility.ROOM_FLOOR && environment[x][y] != DungeonUtility.CAVE_FLOOR) {
642            markEnvironment(x, y, DungeonUtility.CORRIDOR_FLOOR);
643        }
644    }
645
646    /**
647     * Internal use. Marks a point's environment type as a room floor.
648     * @param x x position to mark
649     * @param y y position to mark
650     */
651    protected void markEnvironmentRoom(int x, int y) {
652        if (x > 0 && x < width - 1 && y > 0 && y < height - 1) {
653            markEnvironment(x, y, DungeonUtility.ROOM_FLOOR);
654        }
655    }
656
657    /**
658     * Internal use. Marks a point's environment type as a cave floor.
659     * @param x x position to mark
660     * @param y y position to mark
661     */
662    protected void markEnvironmentCave(int x, int y) {
663        if (x > 0 && x < width - 1 && y > 0 && y < height - 1 && environment[x][y] != DungeonUtility.ROOM_FLOOR) {
664            markEnvironment(x, y, DungeonUtility.CAVE_FLOOR);
665        }
666    }
667    /**
668     * Internal use. Marks a point to be made into floor.
669     * @param x x position to mark
670     * @param y y position to mark
671     */
672    protected void wallOff(int x, int y) {
673        if (x > 0 && x < width - 1 && y > 0 && y < height - 1) {
674            walled[x][y] = true;
675        }
676    }
677
678    /**
679     * Internal use. Marks a point to be made into floor.
680     * @param pos position to mark
681     * @return false if everything is normal, true if and only if this failed to mark because the position is walled
682     */
683    protected boolean mark(Coord pos)
684    {
685        return mark(pos.x, pos.y);
686    }
687
688    /**
689     * Internal use. Marks a point to be made into floor, piercing walls.
690     * @param pos position to mark
691     */
692    protected void markPiercing(Coord pos)
693    {
694        markPiercing(pos.x, pos.y);
695    }
696    /**
697     * Internal use. Marks a point to be made into floor, piercing walls, and also marks the point as a cave floor.
698     * @param pos position to mark
699     */
700    protected void markPiercingCave(Coord pos)
701    {
702        markPiercing(pos.x, pos.y);
703        markEnvironmentCave(pos.x, pos.y);
704    }
705    /**
706     * Internal use. Marks a point to be made into floor, piercing walls, and also marks the point as a room floor.
707     * @param x x coordinate of position to mark
708     * @param y y coordinate of position to mark
709     */
710    protected void markPiercingRoom(int x, int y)
711    {
712        markPiercing(x, y);
713        markEnvironmentCave(x, y);
714    }
715
716    /**
717     * Internal use. Marks a point and the four cells orthogonally adjacent to it.
718     * @param pos center position to mark
719     * @return null if the center of the plus shape wasn't blocked by wall, otherwise the Coord of the center
720     */
721    private Coord markPlus(Coord pos) {
722        Coord block = null;
723        if (mark(pos.x, pos.y))
724            block = pos;
725        mark(pos.x + 1, pos.y);
726        mark(pos.x - 1, pos.y);
727        mark(pos.x, pos.y + 1);
728        mark(pos.x, pos.y - 1);
729        return block;
730    }
731
732    /**
733     * Internal use. Marks a point and the four cells orthogonally adjacent to it, and also marks any cells that weren't
734     * blocked as cave floors.
735     * @param pos center position to mark
736     * @return null if the center of the plus shape wasn't blocked by wall, otherwise the Coord of the center
737     */
738    private Coord markPlusCave(Coord pos) {
739        Coord block = null;
740        if (mark(pos.x, pos.y))
741            block = pos;
742        else
743            markEnvironmentCave(pos.x, pos.y);
744        if(!mark(pos.x + 1, pos.y))
745            markEnvironmentCave(pos.x + 1, pos.y);
746        if(!mark(pos.x - 1, pos.y))
747            markEnvironmentCave(pos.x - 1, pos.y);
748        if(!mark(pos.x, pos.y + 1))
749            markEnvironmentCave(pos.x, pos.y + 1);
750        if(!mark(pos.x, pos.y - 1))
751            markEnvironmentCave(pos.x, pos.y - 1);
752        return block;
753    }
754    /**
755     * Internal use. Marks a rectangle of points centered on pos, extending halfWidth in both x directions and
756     * halfHeight in both vertical directions. Marks all cells in the rectangle as room floors.
757     * @param pos center position to mark
758     * @param halfWidth the distance from the center to extend horizontally
759     * @param halfHeight the distance from the center to extend vertically
760     * @return null if no points in the rectangle were blocked by walls, otherwise a Coord blocked by a wall
761     */
762    private Coord markRectangle(Coord pos, int halfWidth, int halfHeight)
763    {
764        halfWidth = Math.max(1, Math.round(halfWidth * roomWidth));
765        halfHeight = Math.max(1, Math.round(halfHeight * roomHeight));
766        Coord block = null;
767        for (int i = pos.x - halfWidth; i <= pos.x + halfWidth; i++) {
768            for (int j = pos.y - halfHeight; j <= pos.y + halfHeight; j++) {
769                if(mark(i, j))
770                    block = Coord.get(i, j);
771                else
772                    markEnvironmentRoom(i, j);
773            }
774        }
775        return block;
776    }
777    /**
778     * Internal use. Marks a rectangle of points centered on pos, extending halfWidth in both x directions and
779     * halfHeight in both vertical directions. Also considers the area just beyond each wall, but not corners, to be
780     * a blocking wall that can only be passed by corridors and small cave openings. Marks all cells in the rectangle as
781     * room floors.
782     * @param pos center position to mark
783     * @param halfWidth the distance from the center to extend horizontally
784     * @param halfHeight the distance from the center to extend vertically
785     * @return null if no points in the rectangle were blocked by walls, otherwise a Coord blocked by a wall
786     */
787    private Coord markRectangleWalled(Coord pos, int halfWidth, int halfHeight)
788    {
789        halfWidth = Math.max(1, Math.round(halfWidth * roomWidth));
790        halfHeight = Math.max(1, Math.round(halfHeight * roomHeight));
791        Coord block = null;
792        for (int i = pos.x - halfWidth; i <= pos.x + halfWidth; i++) {
793            for (int j = pos.y - halfHeight; j <= pos.y + halfHeight; j++) {
794                markPiercing(i, j);
795                markEnvironmentRoom(i, j);
796            }
797        }
798        for (int i = Math.max(0, pos.x - halfWidth - 1); i <= Math.min(width - 1, pos.x + halfWidth + 1); i++) {
799            for (int j = Math.max(0, pos.y - halfHeight - 1); j <= Math.min(height - 1, pos.y + halfHeight + 1); j++)
800            {
801                wallOff(i, j);
802            }
803        }
804        return block;
805    }
806
807    /**
808     * Internal use. Marks a circle of points centered on pos, extending out to radius in Euclidean measurement. Marks
809     * all cells in the circle as room floors.
810     * @param pos center position to mark
811     * @param radius radius to extend in all directions from center
812     * @return null if no points in the circle were blocked by walls, otherwise a Coord blocked by a wall
813     */
814    private Coord markCircle(Coord pos, int radius)
815    {
816        Coord block = null;
817        int high;
818        radius = Math.max(1, Math.round(radius * Math.min(roomWidth, roomHeight)));
819        for (int dx = -radius; dx <= radius; ++dx)
820        {
821            high = (int)Math.floor(Math.sqrt(radius * radius - dx * dx));
822            for (int dy = -high; dy <= high; ++dy)
823            {
824                if(mark(pos.x + dx, pos.y + dy))
825                    block = pos.translate(dx, dy);
826                else
827                    markEnvironmentRoom(pos.x + dx, pos.y + dy);
828            }
829        }
830        return block;
831    }
832    /**
833     * Internal use. Marks a circle of points centered on pos, extending out to radius in Euclidean measurement.
834     * Also considers the area just beyond each wall, but not corners, to be a blocking wall that can only be passed by
835     * corridors and small cave openings. Marks all cells in the circle as room floors.
836     * @param pos center position to mark
837     * @param radius radius to extend in all directions from center
838     * @return null if no points in the circle were blocked by walls, otherwise a Coord blocked by a wall
839     */
840    private Coord markCircleWalled(Coord pos, int radius)
841    {
842        Coord block = null;
843        int high;
844        radius = Math.max(1, Math.round(radius * Math.min(roomWidth, roomHeight)));
845        for (int dx = -radius; dx <= radius; ++dx)
846        {
847            high = (int)Math.floor(Math.sqrt(radius * radius - dx * dx));
848            for (int dy = -high; dy <= high; ++dy)
849            {
850                markPiercing(pos.x + dx, pos.y + dy);
851                markEnvironmentRoom(pos.x + dx, pos.y + dy);
852            }
853        }
854        for (int dx = -radius; dx <= radius; ++dx)
855        {
856            high = (int)Math.floor(Math.sqrt(radius * radius - dx * dx));
857            int dx2 = Math.max(1, Math.min(pos.x + dx, width - 2));
858            for (int dy = -high; dy <= high; ++dy)
859            {
860                int dy2 = Math.max(1, Math.min(pos.y + dy, height - 2));
861
862                wallOff(dx2, dy2-1);
863                wallOff(dx2+1, dy2-1);
864                wallOff(dx2-1, dy2-1);
865                wallOff(dx2, dy2);
866                wallOff(dx2+1, dy2);
867                wallOff(dx2-1, dy2);
868                wallOff(dx2, dy2+1);
869                wallOff(dx2+1, dy2+1);
870                wallOff(dx2-1, dy2+1);
871
872            }
873        }
874        return block;
875    }
876
877    /**
878     * Internal use. Drunkard's walk algorithm, single step. Based on Michael Patraw's C code, used for cave carving.
879     * http://mpatraw.github.io/libdrunkard/
880     * @param current the current point
881     * @param target the point to wobble towards
882     * @param weight between 0.5 and 1.0, usually. 0.6 makes very random caves, 0.9 is almost a straight line.
883     * @return a Direction, either UP, DOWN, LEFT, or RIGHT if we should move, or NONE if we have reached our target
884     */
885    private Direction stepWobbly(Coord current, Coord target, double weight)
886    {
887        int dx = target.x - current.x;
888        int dy = target.y - current.y;
889
890        if (dx >  1) dx = 1;
891        if (dx < -1) dx = -1;
892        if (dy >  1) dy = 1;
893        if (dy < -1) dy = -1;
894
895        double r = rng.nextDouble();
896        Direction dir;
897        if (dx == 0 && dy == 0)
898        {
899            return Direction.NONE;
900        }
901        else if (dx == 0 || dy == 0)
902        {
903            int dx2 = (dx == 0) ? dx : dy, dy2 = (dx == 0) ? dy : dx;
904            if (r >= (weight * 0.5))
905            {
906                r -= weight * 0.5;
907                if (r < weight * (1.0 / 6) + (1 - weight) * (1.0 / 3))
908                {
909                    dx2 = -1;
910                    dy2 = 0;
911                }
912                else if (r < weight * (2.0 / 6) + (1 - weight) * (2.0 / 3))
913                {
914                    dx2 = 1;
915                    dy2 = 0;
916                }
917                else
918                {
919                    dx2 = 0;
920                    dy2 *= -1;
921                }
922            }
923            dir = Direction.getCardinalDirection(dx2, -dy2);
924
925        }
926        else
927        {
928            if (r < weight * 0.5)
929            {
930                dy = 0;
931            }
932            else if (r < weight)
933            {
934                dx = 0;
935            }
936            else if (r < weight + (1 - weight) * 0.5)
937            {
938                dx *= -1;
939                dy = 0;
940            }
941            else
942            {
943                dx = 0;
944                dy *= -1;
945            }
946            dir = Direction.getCardinalDirection(dx, -dy);
947        }
948        if(current.x + dir.deltaX <= 0 || current.x + dir.deltaX >= width - 1) {
949            if (current.y < target.y) dir = Direction.DOWN;
950            else if (current.y > target.y) dir = Direction.UP;
951        }
952        else if(current.y + dir.deltaY <= 0 || current.y + dir.deltaY >= height - 1) {
953            if (current.x < target.x) dir = Direction.RIGHT;
954            else if (current.x > target.x) dir = Direction.LEFT;
955        }
956        return dir;
957    }
958
959}
